title-group.article-title: Housing outcomes among homeless-experienced Veterans engaged in vocational services

article-meta.aff: 1VA HSR&D Center for the Study of Healthcare Innovation, Implementation & Policy (CSHIIP), VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System
2Vocational Rehabilitation Services, VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System
3National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans, U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs
4School of Public Health, University of Alabama at Birmingham
5VA Rehabilitation R&D Center on Enhancement of Community Integration for Homeless Veterans, VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence concerning this article should be addressed to Michelle S Wong VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System, 11301 Wilshire Blvd, Building 206, Los Angeles, CA 90073 Michelle.Wong6@va.gov Phone: (310) 478-3711 x 49955

fn.p: We have no known conflict of interest to disclose.

abstract.p: Though unemployment and homelessness are closely intertwined, vocational services are rarely prioritized for homeless-experienced individuals engaging in housing services. Our goal was to examine associations between vocational service use and housing outcomes among homeless-experienced Veterans engaged in permanent supportive housing. We obtained data from Veterans Health Administration (VA) medical record and homelessness registry data for homeless-experienced Veterans engaged in VA Greater Los Angeles’ permanent supportive housing program from 10/2016–9/2017 (n=1,200). We used multivariate logistic regression to examine whether vocational service use was associated with housing attainment and/or premature permanent supportive housing exits. We found that Veterans in permanent supportive housing who used vocational services were more likely to attain housing (OR=2.52, p-value<0.001) than their peers who did not use these services. There were no between-group differences in the odds of premature exits from the permanent supportive housing program (OR=1.92, p-value=0.425). Our study suggests that, among homeless-experienced Veterans engaged in permanent supportive housing programs, those who use vocational services potentially may be more likely to attain housing. However, future research can better elucidate the pathways underlying vocational service use and housing outcomes for individuals in permanent supportive housing programs. Greater integration of vocational services and permanent supportive housing programs, and encouragement of vocational service use may enhance housing outcomes among permanent supportive housing participants.
